title: 22 Fitness Pros Share Their Favorite Abs Exercises
text: 22 Fitness Pros Share Their Favorite Abs Exercises Time to get burning. Share via Twitter FatCamera / Getty Images There are only so many ways you can do crunches or planks before you get bored. But that's no reason to skip a core session. A strong torso sets the stage for any movement, from squats to sprints. Strong abdominal muscles also help protect your lower back, meaning fewer aches. Switching up your abs exercises helps you be sure to hit every muscle group from different angles We asked 22 trainers to share their go-to core move so you can add it into your rotation. Simply pick and choose a different move every time you feel the need to pepper in something new to your core sets. Be prepared to feel that oh-so-good soreness that hurts when you laugh—we promise it's worth it. AKT 1 Side passe dip from Anna Kaiser of AKT "This doubles as a great arm toning move. At AKT, we love to treat the body as a whole, rather than just isolating one body part," Anna Kaiser, founder of AKT, tells SELF. Start in a side plank with your right hand under your right shoulder. Keeping your left foot flat (as shown), lift your right foot to your left knee, also called "in passe." Dip your right hip to tap the floor. Return to start. That's one rep. Repeat 10 times. Switch sides and repeat. Box + Flow 2 Uppercut from Olivia Young of Box + Flow As founder of box + flow , Olivia Young designs workouts that kill your abs in 55 minutes. "Both boxing and yoga are all about your core; that's where your strength comes from," Young tells SELF. Her move of choice? "I love uppercuts. They work your obliques like nothing else." Start in a fighter's stance with your feet staggered and your arms protecting your face (as shown). Slip to your left, dropping left shoulder. Slip back to the right as your left hand comes up in an uppercut punch. Pow! Make it harder and do the move with 1-pound weights in each hand. ChaiseFitness 3 Attitude ab curl from Rachel Piskin of ChaiseFitness The cofounder of pilates - and ballet-inspired fitness studio ChaiseFitness , Rachel Piskin, likes this move because targets the lower abdominal area with the control and release of your leg. Plus you'll also feel it working your thighs and glutes, too. Start on your back with right leg raised toward the ceiling and your left toe touching the floor (as shown above). Place your hands behind your head. Raise your upper back off the floor as you bring your left heel up to meet the right. Return to start for one rep. Repeat 20 times on each side. The Bar Method Kickstand curl from Kiesha Ramey-Presner of The Bar Method As a master instructor at The Bar Method, Kiesha Ramey-Presner is no stranger to abs moves. Start faceup on your back with elbows at sides. Align your elbows under your shoulders and hold your fists up. Keep your feet flat, hip-width apart. Tighten your glutes and press your lower back into floor. Curl forward. Exhale and pull your abs in. Return to start for one rep. Repeat 10 times slowly, rest, then 20 times quickly. ChaiseFitness 5 Teaser from Claudia Aarts-Schreiber of ChaiseFitness “At ChaiseFitness, we use elastic resistance bands or bungees to help clients find their perfect posture while engaging the core," Claudia Aarts-Schreiber, owner and instructor at ChaiseFitness in Madison, New Jersey, tells SELF. Sit on a mat and place a resistance band around arches of your feet. Tighten the band to keep resistance between your feet and arms. Sit tall and bring your elbows into your waist. Then curl your torso back 6 to 8 inches. Drag your heels in toward your butt, then slowly lift them up to table top (as shown on left). Hold for 10 to 15 seconds for one rep, and repeat 3 times. If you want to make it harder, extend your legs (as shown on right). Amanda Kloots 6 Such a Teaser from Amanda Kloots of The Rope As founder of The Rope, a jump rope–focused class, Amanda Kloots uses the rope in all sorts of innovative and fun ways. "This move targets your whole core, with a great focus on the obliques," Kloots tells SELF. Lie faceup with the rope pulled tight around your feet. Grasp the handles. Slowly roll your torso up until you're sitting upright. As you do, lift your arms above your head to keep the rope tight (as shown on left). The next step: Reach your right arm out to the side, touch the floor, and return; repeat on the left side. Repeat with both arms at the same time, then return to start. That's one rep. Repeat 8 times. Heather Lilleston Rocking plank from Heather Lilleston of Yoga For Bad People This move "is a simple strong plank , great for training the body's muscular makeup to support the whole body equally, where you rock forward and back on your wrists," cofounder of Yoga For Bad People Heather Lilleston tells SELF. Start in a plank with your arms extended. Keep your shoulders and elbows over your wrists. Slowly rock back toward your heels (as shown on the left) and then back over your wrists (as shown on the right). Continue this motion for the length of an entire song, "the slower, the better," Lilleston says. If you need a modification, hold yourself up on your forearms and repeat the motion. Nicole De Anda 8 Ball balance from Nicole De Anda of Equinox "There's no cheating [with this move]! Adding the prop causes you to slow down and focus,“ Nicole De Anda, the creator of Trilogy Barre at Equinox, tells SELF. "This sequence is incredibly effective at promoting deep [core] muscle engagement," De Anda tells SELF. You’ll need a small unweighted playground ball for this one. Lie on your back, legs in tabletop position, knees together. Place the ball on top of your shins and ensure that the ball is balanced. Interlace your hands behind your head (as shown). Curl your shoulder blades off the mat. Without letting the ball fall, slowly begin to extend your legs away from you until they reach full extension. Keep your low back pressed into the mat. Pause, then slowly begin to draw the legs back in toward tabletop position. That's one rep. Repeat 8 to 12 times. YogaSpark 9 Warrior III from Lauren Porat of YogaSpark The founder of YogaSpark chose a move you've likely seen before, Warrior III, but it may not have been the one that immediately comes to mind as an abdominal exercise. "I truly believe that almost your entire yoga class can and should be viewed as a core strengthener! A healthy core will support you better in many poses and series," Lauren Porat tells SELF. This single-leg move will test your balance, and a strong center will help prevent wobbling. Balance on one leg and lean forward, raising the other leg. Simultaneously lower your torso until it's parallel to the floor. Keep your hands at heart (as shown). To help your balance and really work your abs, think about drawing your navel in toward your spine. Keep your hips in line. Fhitting Room Side plank from Jason Tran of The Fhitting Room "Side planks strengthen your abs, back, and obliques," Jason Tran, trainer at The Fhitting Room, tells SELF. Start in a side plank on your left, propping your body up with your forearm, left elbow directly under your shoulder. Keep a straight line from your shoulders to your feet (as shown). If you want to make it easier, place your right foot on the floor in front of your left knee. For more of a challenge, raise your top leg and hold. Tanya Becker 11 Reverse curl from Tanya Becker of Physique57 You'll work your abdominal wall and lower-back muscles with this move, Tanya Becker, cofounder and chief creative officer at Physique 57, tells SELF. Lie faceup a few inches from a wall. Press your hands into the wall, fingertips down, elbows pointed toward the ceiling. Lift your legs above your hips. Bend your knees slightly if needed. Keeping your hands pressed to the wall, engage your abs and lift your hips toward the ceiling. Return to start. That's one rep. Repeat. For even more of a challenge, twist your hips from side to side as you lift them. Lisa Corsello 12 Pilates twist from Lisa Corsello of Burn Pilates Creator of Burn Pilates Lisa Corsello loves this challenging move. "In addition to getting a major oblique burn, I feel it in my shoulders and glutes. I love movements that incorporate many different areas of the body. Much more bang for your buck," she tells SELF. Sit on your right hip with your knees bent, as shown at left. Cross your ankles; your right heel should touch your left toe. Straighten your legs, push all your weight into your right arm, and lift your hips to come into a side plank. Once you're there, reach your top arm toward the ceiling as you inhale, then exhale and send your arm down under your hip. Lift both hips into a semi-pike, and reach your arm behind you toward the mat. Return to the plank and come back to your starting pose. That's one rep. Andia Winslow Track & field from Andia Winslow Also known as single-leg bent-knee tucks, this exercise mimics sprinting on a track. "Not only does this move work your midsection, but it will get your heart pumping as you speed up arm and leg action," says Andia Winslow, founder of The Fit Cycle, professional golfer, and sports performance coach. "You’ll develop coordination skills to boot," she tells SELF. Sit with your feet outstretched in front of you, back straight (as shown on left). Extend left leg and bring right leg toward your chest (as shown on right). Switch legs and pump your arms as if you're running. Fhitting Room Hollow hold from Dennys Lozada of The Fhitting Room "My go-to ab move is the hollow hold because it works your entire core. A hollow hold can easily be scaled so anyone can effectively perform the movement regardless of fitness level," Dennys Lozada, trainer at The Fhitting Room tells SELF. Lie faceup with your arms on the floor above your head. Lift your legs about 30 degrees. Raise your upper back, head, and arms off the floor. Hold this position, squeezing your core, for as long as possible. To make it easier, bring your arms down by your sides, or bend one leg at a time to prevent lower-back discomfort. For a challenge, add a rocking motion back and forth while maintaining the hollow body shape. Lauren Imparato 15 Ab extension from Lauren Imparato of I.AM.YOU Studio "I love these ab exercises because like everything RETOX , they are unconventional and highly effective," Lauren Imparato, author of RETOX and founder of I.AM.YOU Studio, tells SELF. Start in a plank with your arms extended, shoulders over your wrists. Lift your right arm to align with your right ear while your left leg rises off the ground. Pause. Return to start and repeat on the opposite side. Sadie Kurzban 16 Plank to pike from Sadie Kurzban of 305 Fitness "I love this move because it works deep core muscles and also strengthens your shoulders and upper back muscles," says Sadie Kurzban, founder of ((305))Fitness . "I use it as a warm-up for cardio, because it increases blood flow all over and helps me engage my core before doing high-impact moves," she tells SELF. You'll need gliders or a towel for this one. Start in a straight-arm plank with your feet on a towel or gliders (as shown on left). Shift your weight into your hands and raise your hips. Allow your heels to rise off the floor (as shown on right). Make sure to put as much weight as possible onto your hands. You should feel a pull in your lower abdominal area, not your hips. Tone House 17 Toes to bar from Alonzo Wilson of Tone House For this exercise, you'll need to head to a gym unless you have a pull-up bar in your home. Director of training at Tone House , Alonzo Wilson, recommends this move to work your lower and upper abs. Hang from a bar with your legs straight, as shown by Tone House's James McMillan on the left. Bring your legs up slowly until toes are at the bar (or as high as you can go) and hold for three counts. Return to start. Repeat 10 times. Don't allow your body to swing back and forth or use momentum to lift your legs! Katia Pryce 18 Ab twist from Katia Pryce of Dancebody Founder of Dancebody Katia Pryce loves squeezing in a great dance move wherever she can. This exercise doesn't require much space, so feel free to break it out at any point in your day. Stand with your feet about hip-distance apart, right foot forward and right arm overhead (as shown on left). Contract your abs and pull your right elbow toward the right hip as it twists forward (as shown on right). Return to start for one rep. Do 24 times. Switch sides and repeat. Katherine Greiner 19 Bear from Katherine Greiner of KG Body "This can be done on a pilates reformer or simply on the floor with a dish towel. It's great for strengthening the entire core but specifically targets the lower abs ," trainer Katherine Greiner tells SELF. Begin in straight-arm plank with a towel under your toes (as shown on left). Slowly draw your knees toward hands on the sliding towel. Keep your hips at shoulder level so your back is flat and parallel to the floor. Return to start and continue for one minute. Allison Berry 20 Dead bug from Allison Berry of Crunch "The reason I am such a fan of this exercise is because it works all parts of the core—not just the superficial muscles, but also the lower back and deeper muscles that support your spine and make you strong," Allison Berry, a trainer with Crunch Fitness, tells SELF. Lie faceup with your arms raised toward the ceiling. Lift your feet off the floor and bend your knees to 90 degrees (as shown on left). Extend your right arm back in line with your ear as you straighten your left leg (as shown on right). Exhale and hold for a count of three. Return to start and repeat on the opposite side. That's one rep. Do 6 times. Repeat the series 3 times. Ashley Wilking 21 Knee to elbow​ from Ashley Wilking of Barry's Bootcamp "As a trainer, I'll always stress the importance of core work . Your core is the basis for stabilization, weight lifting, and practically any movement in and out of the gym," Ashley Wilking, a trainer with Barry's Bootcamp, tells SELF. "My favorite? Side planks, targeting those fabulous obliques," she adds. Start in a left side plank on your forearm. Keep your shoulder directly over your elbow. Stagger your feet so that your top foot is in front of your back foot. Place your top hand behind your head (as shown on left). The move: Lift your left foot off the ground and crunch your knee to your elbow (as shown on right). Abbey Woodfin 22 Low plank hip drop from Abbey Woodfin of Modelfit "These are great for strengthening the core, especially the obliques, abs, and low back!" trainer Abbey Woodfin of Modelfit tells SELF. Start in a low plank with your forearms under your shoulders (as shown on left). Rotate at your waist to drop your right hip to the ground. Bring it back to neutral before rotating the waist to the left and dropping the left hip down. Return to neutral. That's one rep.
